question: Which muscle is innervated by the long thoracic nerve?
short_explanation: The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior.
long_explanation: The long thoracic nerve arises from roots C5–C7 and travels superficially to innervate the serratus anterior, critical for scapular protraction and stabilization.
applied_example: Clients with scapular winging may have long thoracic nerve injury, often due to trauma or repetitive overhead activity.
text: Which muscle is innervated by the long thoracic nerve?

question: Which spinal roots give rise to the long thoracic nerve?
short_explanation: The long thoracic nerve is formed from C5, C6, and C7.
long_explanation: Emerging from the roots of the brachial plexus, the long thoracic nerve originates from C5–C7 and travels along the thoracic wall to the serratus anterior.
applied_example: Knowledge of nerve roots aids in identifying proximal injuries from brachial plexus compression or surgery.
text: Which spinal roots give rise to the long thoracic nerve?

question: Damage to the long thoracic nerve may result in which clinical sign?
short_explanation: Winging scapula is the hallmark of long thoracic nerve injury.
long_explanation: The serratus anterior anchors the scapula to the rib cage. When denervated, the medial scapula protrudes posteriorly when pushing forward—scapular winging.
applied_example: Therapists assessing posture or push-up mechanics may spot subtle scapular instability linked to long thoracic dysfunction.
text: Damage to the long thoracic nerve may result in which clinical sign?

question: Which of the following movements is primarily impaired by long thoracic nerve injury?
short_explanation: Scapular protraction is impaired due to serratus anterior paralysis.
long_explanation: The serratus anterior is crucial for forward movement and upward rotation of the scapula, such as in reaching or punching.
applied_example: Boxers or swimmers may lose power and fluidity in arm movements if scapular control is disrupted.
source_reference: Kinesiology of the Musculoskeletal System, Neumann
text: Which of the following movements is primarily impaired by long thoracic nerve injury?

question: Why is the long thoracic nerve vulnerable to injury?
answers: It lies deep within the chest wall
It travels on the superficial surface of the serratus anterior
It is located in the spinal canal
short_explanation: The long thoracic nerve is superficially located and exposed during movement or trauma.
long_explanation: Its superficial path along the lateral thorax makes it susceptible to injury from blows, surgery, or repetitive overhead use.
applied_example: Massage therapists should avoid deep pressure over the lateral ribs in post-op or athletic clients.
text: Why is the long thoracic nerve vulnerable to injury?
options: It lies deep within the chest wall
It travels on the superficial surface of the serratus anterior
It is located in the spinal canal
correctAnswer: It travels on the superficial surface of the serratus anterior
abcd: A. It lies deep within the chest wall
C. It travels on the superficial surface of the serratus anterior
D. It is located in the spinal canal

question: Which activity would be most affected by long thoracic nerve palsy?
short_explanation: Overhead reaching requires scapular rotation, which depends on serratus anterior.
long_explanation: Tasks like reaching high shelves require coordinated scapular movement. Loss of serratus anterior causes fatigue, pain, or dysfunction in these motions.
applied_example: Massage clients with neck/shoulder complaints should be screened for serratus dysfunction when reporting difficulty lifting arms.
text: Which activity would be most affected by long thoracic nerve palsy?

question: Which clinical test is used to assess long thoracic nerve function?
short_explanation: The wall push-up test highlights scapular winging.
long_explanation: Instruct the client to push against a wall with both arms extended. A protruding medial border of the scapula indicates serratus weakness.
applied_example: Useful in sports rehab and massage settings to track scapular stabilization progress or screen dysfunction.
text: Which clinical test is used to assess long thoracic nerve function?

question: The long thoracic nerve innervates its target muscle on which side?
short_explanation: It runs along the lateral chest wall.
long_explanation: The long thoracic nerve travels on the lateral aspect of the rib cage to innervate the serratus anterior from its external surface.
applied_example: Therapists should visualize this lateral route when palpating ribs or working on thoracic fascia.
text: The long thoracic nerve innervates its target muscle on which side?

question: Which of the following is NOT a typical cause of long thoracic nerve damage?
short_explanation: Neck fractures usually don’t affect the long thoracic nerve.
long_explanation: Compression (e.g., backpack straps), surgery (e.g., lymph node dissection), and repetitive strain are common causes of long thoracic nerve palsy.
applied_example: Massage practitioners should take client history of post-op breast, shoulder, or axillary surgery into account.
text: Which of the following is NOT a typical cause of long thoracic nerve damage?

question: Which brachial plexus region gives rise to the long thoracic nerve?
short_explanation: It branches directly from the roots (C5–C7).
long_explanation: Unlike many other nerves of the upper limb, the long thoracic nerve arises directly from the roots of the brachial plexus before they combine into trunks.
applied_example: This root-level origin makes it vulnerable during traction injuries or cervical plexus strain.
text: Which brachial plexus region gives rise to the long thoracic nerve?
